event: 1943 - The U.S. Navy patrol torpedo boat PT-109, commanded by Lieutenant (junior grade) John F. Kennedy, is rammed and sunk by the Japanese destroyer Amagiri off the Solomon Islands.
1990 - Iraq invades Kuwait, leading to the beginning of the Persian Gulf War. The U.S. would launch Operation Desert Shield five days later to defend Saudi Arabia.
1958 - The U.S. nuclear submarine USS Nautilus completes the first-ever undersea voyage to the geographic North Pole, a significant Cold War achievement.
1790 - The U.S. Coast Guard is founded as the Revenue-Marine by Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton, making it the oldest continuous seagoing service of the United States.
1864 - During the Battle of Mobile Bay, Union Admiral David Farragut famously orders, 'Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead!' leading to a decisive victory for the Union Navy.
1945 - The B-29 bomber 'Enola Gay' of the U.S. Army Air Forces drops the atomic bomb 'Little Boy' on the city of Hiroshima, Japan, in an effort to end World War II.
1782 - General George Washington establishes the Badge of Military Merit to honor soldiers for 'any singularly meritorious action.' It is the direct predecessor of the modern Purple Heart.
1918 - The Battle of Amiens begins, marking the start of the Hundred Days Offensive, the Allied counterattack that would ultimately lead to the end of World War I.
1945 - The B-29 bomber 'Bockscar' drops the atomic bomb 'Fat Man' on the city of Nagasaki, Japan. Japan would announce its surrender six days later.
1949 - The National Security Act Amendments of 1949 are signed, transforming the National Military Establishment into the modern, centralized Department of Defense.
1972 - The last U.S. ground combat unit, the Third Battalion, Twenty-First Infantry, departs from South Vietnam, ending years of direct American military engagement.
1981 - IBM introduces the Personal Computer (PC), a technology that would revolutionize everything from civilian life to military command, control, and intelligence operations.
1942 - The 'Manhattan Project' is formally established to develop the atomic bomb, a top-secret endeavor combining the efforts of U.S., British, and Canadian scientists.
1945 - President Harry S. Truman announces Japan's unconditional surrender, effectively ending World War II. The day becomes known as Victory over Japan Day, or V-J Day.
1940 - The first official parachute jump of the U.S. Army's Parachute Test Platoon at Fort Benning, Georgia, marks the birth of U.S. military airborne forces.
1944 - Operation Dragoon, the Allied invasion of Southern France, begins with a massive amphibious and airborne assault involving the U.S. Seventh Army.
1942 - U.S. Marines from the 2nd Raider Battalion conduct a daring 'hit-and-run' raid on Makin Atoll in the Pacific, an early special operations mission of WWII.
1965 - Operation Starlite begins in Vietnam. It is the first major offensive conducted purely by U.S. ground forces, marking a significant escalation of American involvement.
1981 - Two U.S. Navy F-14 Tomcats shoot down two Libyan Su-22 fighter jets over the Gulf of Sidra, after the Libyan aircraft fired upon the American planes in international airspace.
1998 - The U.S. military launches cruise missile strikes (Operation Infinite Reach) against al-Qaeda camps in Afghanistan in retaliation for the bombings of U.S. embassies in Africa.
1959 - Hawaii is admitted as the 50th U.S. state. Its strategic location is home to the headquarters of the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command and the Pacific Fleet.
1977 - The first flight of the U.S. Army's YAH-64, the prototype for the AH-64 Apache attack helicopter, takes place. The Apache would become a dominant force on the battlefield.
1996 - Osama bin Laden issues his first fatwa, a 'Declaration of War against the Americans Occupying the Land of the Two Holy Places,' setting the stage for future attacks.
1814 - During the War of 1812, British forces capture Washington, D.C., and set fire to numerous public buildings, including the White House and the Capitol Building.
1944 - Allied forces, including the French 2nd Armored Division and the U.S. 4th Infantry Division, liberate the city of Paris from German occupation.
1992 - The U.S. begins enforcing a no-fly zone over southern Iraq (Operation Southern Watch) to protect populations from Saddam Hussein's regime.
1962 - The U.S. launches the Mariner 2 space probe, the first successful robotic interplanetary probe. Its technology laid the groundwork for modern satellite reconnaissance.
1963 - Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his 'I Have a Dream' speech. Many veterans of the armed forces were key participants and provided security for the Civil Rights Movement.
2005 - Hurricane Katrina makes landfall, leading to one of the largest domestic deployments of the U.S. National Guard and active-duty military in American history for disaster relief.
1963 - The Moscow-Washington hotline, a direct communication link between the leaders of the U.S. and the Soviet Union, becomes operational to prevent accidental nuclear war.
2021 - The final U.S. military planes depart from Kabul, officially ending the 20-year War in Afghanistan and concluding the largest non-combatant evacuation in U.S. history.
1939 - Germany invades Poland, initiating World War II in Europe. This event would ultimately draw the United States into the largest and deadliest conflict in human history.
